explanation: The report is correct. The only check that data is non-NULL when length>0 is performed via mhd_assert ((data != NULL) || (length == 0)). If that macro is compiled out (as is common for assert-like macros in release builds), there is no runtime guarantee that data is valid when length>0. Subsequent calls to memcpy (and the md5_transform calls that read from data) will then dereference data and can access memory beyond the bounds of the object referenced by the data pointer (or dereference a NULL pointer). That is exactly what MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 forbids. To comply, the code must perform an unconditional runtime check (or otherwise ensure by contract/enforcement that data is non-NULL when length>0) before calling memcpy or other string/memory functions.
